text: Good evening to everyone. I now call this October 22nd meeting of the Albemarle County School Board to order. We will have a moment of silence.  Thank you. Because of the pandemic, we are required to read this statement into our minutes. The minutes of this meeting should reflect that this meeting is being held electronically, pursuant to Virginia state law and Albemarle County ordinance, because the COVID-19 pandemic makes it impracticable and unsafe to assemble a quorum physically in a single location.  The meeting is being communicated to the public electronically through Zoom and streamed live on the Albemarle County Public Schools website. And public comment may be offered through the Zoom waiting room feature in accordance with the school board's protocol or by written submission. And also tonight we have another statement that we hope our listeners will be aware of and adhere to.  I'd like to quote from a paragraph that is in our policy on school community relations. It says in part, the school board recognizes the public has vast resources of training and experience. And I add perspectives that are useful to schools. The strength of our school system is in the degree to which these resources are tapped in an advisory way. And these resources are involved in supporting the improvement of our educational program.  Broad and diverse community engagement with the work of the board and the school division is so important that its value is expressly stated in the policy. Everyone is encouraged to offer their ideas, judgments, concerns, and questions about how well the school division is serving the needs of students and contributing to the health, safety, and economic prosperity of our community.  The live streaming of school board meetings office of that valuable opportunity to benefit from the voices of more parents, students, employees and community partners. Since the pandemic participation in school board meetings often has gone from less than 25 people to more than 1000.  We'd like to build on this growing community interest. Beginning this evening, those who accessed our live stream link will be offered a brief survey that will help us to expand our community outreach and contributions. Please take a few minutes to help with this goal. So if you are listening to our meeting, please take that opportunity at the end of the meeting, at the end of this session. Now for the introduction of our school board members, Dr. Kate Acuff,

text: Thank you, Mr. Page. I'm going to start by reading the public comment guidelines.  The school board invites and actively seeks the public's input in the matters relevant to school board governance and provides for time during its business meetings to hear from Albemarle County residents and community members.  As authorized by ordinance of the County of Albemarle, the school board will hold its meetings electronically during the COVID-19 pandemic. The school board is, nevertheless, committed to encouraging public comment despite meeting on a virtual basis. For this reason, there will be two ways for the public to provide comment. First, as always, written comments may be submitted to the school board clerk prior to the start of the meeting and will be given to all the school board members for review.  And as long as the school board member holds its meetings electronically, members of the public wishing to provide public comment during the meeting may sign up online by 2 p.m. the day of the meeting. Before electronic public comment starts, I'm going to announce the order in which the speakers are going to comment. Each speaker's access to public comment will be activated when it's your turn. Speakers will be notified when they reach the two-minute mark and at the three-minute mark. And that's usually just me holding up one finger when you have one minute left.  Speakers during the meeting are those submitting written comments should state their name and address our magisterial district and further speaker should limit comments or try to limit comments to those matters that are relevant to school board governance or the operation of the school division.  Lastly, although the school board will not respond to comments made during the public comment period, school board members may address comments at the end of the meeting agenda under other business. With that, let me pull up the public comment list. We have four speakers today. The first is going to be Margaret Lowry-Keppel. The second is going to be Michelle Drago. The third is going to be Amy Gertner. And the fourth is going to be Kenneth Martin. Ms. Keppel, if you are on, it is your turn.
speaker: katrinacallsen

text: I am good evening. My name is Margaret Keppel. I am a homeschooling resident of the Ravanna district. And I'm here tonight to ask that the staff at Albemarle High School, please follow Virginia state law and register my daughter, Elizabeth for the AP European history test. The code of Virginia section 221-254.1.f states school boards shall make advanced placement  preliminary SAT national merit scholarship qualifying test and pre ACT examinations available to students receiving home instruction pursuant to this section. The school board shall adopt written policies that specify the date by which such students shall register to participate in such examinations. School boards shall notify such students and their parents of such registration deadline and the availability of financial assistance to low income  and needy students to take such examinations. I have not been informed, and I've been homeschooling since 2004, so I've really never been informed of SAT deadlines and AP deadlines, which has not been a big deal for me because I just figure it out and call the school and make the appointments. But I did want to just mention that whoever handles that section of the  of the public school system in Albemarle might start doing that since it is written there that that should be being done. I do understand or have figured out that November 13th or 15th is the deadline for registering for the AP exam. And so there is some urgency here, hence my wanting to come to this school board meeting and mention it. I also have a private school student, a son who would like to register for the same exam.  Those are my comments. Thanks so much for your support. I don't know, accounting has always been really good to homeschoolers. So I'm not angry. text: Hi, my name is Michelle Drago and I am a member of the right Vienna district. I've been a kindergarten and first grade teacher for 12 years here in Charlottesville.  And I'm here tonight to talk about the county's mask policy on behalf of hundreds of other educators that we have been in contact with in the last few days. On the Return to School website, as of 6.21 p.m. tonight, the mask policy said, students and employees shall wear a mask or acceptable face covering at all times, regardless of physical distancing, in an ACPS school building, in another ACPS facility, on a school property or campus, or in an ACPS vehicle or bus.  That was very clear that was very wise and this makes sense given all CDC guidelines regarding safety protocols for gathering in groups, and for state guidelines regarding masks and other closed air environments like Virginia stores or other places where people are congregating.  However, in a tab that is closed unless opened by the reader further down, it says students may remove masks and face coverings on a case by case basis for specific instructional needs or activities or is otherwise determined by a teacher, including to provide a brief respite from wearing a mask or face covering. In this event, six feet of physical distancing as approved by ACPS must be maintained.  That part is not clear, that part is not wise, that part does not make sense given CDC guidelines regarding safety protocols or given what we know we need to do in other closed-air environments. The two statements oppose each other. It is like a teacher saying, you may not tease anyone in my class, but you can if the teacher gives you permission on a case-by-case basis.  There is such a thing as wise decision-making and it needs to be done in a very clear way in a time where public health is at risk. The mask policy is irresponsible and reckless. The lack of clarity opens teachers up to complaints and different interpretations. Some teachers will be seen as the good guys who let their kids take masks off for a bit. Others will be the bad guys who make them keep them on. A student or parent who wishes to not wear a mask could possibly use the ambiguity of this statement to complain or overrule a teacher.  This puts the burden of deciding whether to enforce mask wearing at all times to each teacher in each grade at each school. That's not acceptable. Leadership needs to make the decision themselves. That is the only way we can try to protect our staff, students, and families. Right now, we know that that does not necessarily apply to certain students with developmental conditions and health conditions, and that makes sense.  However, we are talking about the broad scale and it says leadership is expecting teachers, excuse me, I'm saying leadership is expecting teachers to have to make the hard decision to draw the line on mask wearing. This does not feel wise this feels a bit cowardly leadership cannot hide behind the teachers and expect us to bear this burden, in addition to everything that we are having to bear now already.  If even one teacher is too scared to insist that all students wear masks at all times because they might be opening themselves up to disagreement. The teacher, the other students in the class, the kids who ride that bus, play with them at recess, and family members of all people who come into contact with these students are at risk.  Teachers will not return to the building. Some of them, because of this, if they know that they might not have students wearing masks at all times, despite the very clear wording at the top of the phrase.
speaker: michelledrago

text: Good evening, members of the board, Dr. Haas, and ACPS employees and families. My name is Amy Gertner, and I'm a resident of the Whitehall District. Thank you again for coming to hear the questions and concerns of members of this community. I'm currently serving as the president of the Albemarle Education Association. We are very concerned how the mask policy the AEA advocated for this summer is being presented. The wearing of a mask is not an option in this community. An indoor mask break does not keep everyone safe in a school building.  Teachers do not want the responsibilities of regulating an inside mass break. The AA officers met with Dr. Haas in his cabinet yesterday. A cabinet member suggested using an out-of-the-way corner of the classroom where students could remove their masks for a break. If you've ever been in a classroom with young children, you know that once one student needs to go to the bathroom or get a drink of water, go to see the nurse, all the students will need to do this as well. Are teachers being asked to consider posting a mass break schedule in their classrooms?  This would make sense if we were not talking about a virus that spreads through the air. Smoking sections in restaurants did not work to keep others safe. This is like proposing a corner of the swimming pool in which to pee. If this virus is present, it's going to spread throughout the room. Every child that sits or stands in a corner will be breathing and touching the surfaces in this area. Masks are what we wear in public. They're not optional. The COVID virus does not take a break because we're uncomfortable.  My youngest nephew was quite shocked when he learned he would be required and expected to wear underwear every day in kindergarten. Yes, every day. We learned to live with the discomfort of our clothing, clothes, coats, shoes. We asked the board to give us the policy with clear expectations of wearing a mask at all times while in our public buildings. We asked that you put the safety of our students, staff, and families first. I want the board members to know that many ACPS bus drivers are AEA members as well. They reached out to the AEA to advocate for their  regarding their safety. I submitted their questions and concerns and they were in yesterday's agenda. We were told Jim Foley would be sending an email to the transportation department in a day or two to address these issues. Some drivers are feeling anxious and discouraged because they feel their needs have not been heard or addressed in a timely manner. I want to end this short lesson with the toothpaste tube. Elementary students and teachers will recognize this activity. This tube is to remind us to be careful with our words  Once the words leave our mouths, they cannot be put back into the tube. Our roads are like toothpaste. There were comments made at the last school board meeting that were hurtful and educators took offense. I hope this will remind everyone to be kind and respectful to one another. We do have the same goals and responsibilities to keep students, families, staff in this community physically and emotionally safe. Thank you for this time this evening and for listening to the concerns of others. Thank you.
speaker: amy

The album all Charlottesville branch of the NAACP supports.  The recent decision by the album all county school board to began on November 9 2020 phase 3 of the approved. The opening guidelines for pre K through 3rd grade.  We seek to ensure all students will have equal access to adequate instruction, resources and materials necessary for proficient academic performance as determined by the standards of learning. We seek also to mitigate the effects of the disruptions in the orderly processes of the Albemarle County Public Schools in order to control the spread of this pandemic.  Academic virtual learning is still in its developmental stage and it is mainly experimental locally. For this reason, every teacher began the fall 2020 session the same as first year teachers. Students, particularly those in the primary grades, are at the beginning stages of learning how to learn academically.  They can benefit most from their teachers employing the skill sets, experience and expertise they have acquired throughout their years of successful teaching. Of course, all students can, but this decision is crucial because successful primary years usually set the foundation for future academic progress.  Our branch of the NAACP is certain that you will employ the necessary protocols and procedures that have demonstrated success in other localities and that the necessary safeguards for the safety of students and employees will be in place when phase three begins. Thank you for allowing me to speak.

text: Yes, thanks Dr. Haas and good evening board members. I'm Pat McLaughlin, chief of strategic planning. And I wanted to give you two brief updates tonight. One on our school calendar and another on an opportunity in which many of our students are participating. First, our school calendar has been updated so that Monday, November 2nd is now a trade-off day for parent conferences. November 2nd will be an instructional day for students. However, all instruction will be asynchronous for them and our buildings will be closed to all students. There'll be no in-person access.  Teachers can use November 2nd for parent conferences or they may set up conferences outside of school hours and use November 2nd as a trade off day for that time. And as you know, Tuesday, November 3rd is election day and is now Virginia State holiday.  November 3rd was already approved as a non-student day and a non-work day for 10-month staff on our 2020-2021 school calendar, and that's now a holiday for all of our 11- and 12-month employees as well. Essential personnel who must open schools to be used as polling places on November 3rd will be granted a floating holiday that they can use at their convenience. A majority of our schools are used as polling stations, and with the exception of access for voting, all of our school buildings will be closed to staff, students, and the public on November 3rd.  And on that note, we were recently contacted by Michael Quinn, a volunteer with the Albemarle County Election Board.  Mr Quinn was looking for help finding student volunteers for the election day page program. That program is open exclusively to high school students and pages work in five hour shifts at our polling places from 5am until 8pm on election day. Mr Quinn worked with john hobson one of our lead coaches to get the word out about this opportunity and it gives me great pleasure to let the board know that Mr Quinn has successfully recruited 140 high school volunteers and of those 140 students 136 are from Albemarle county public schools.  Mr. Quinn reports that he continues to get between six and 10 applications each day. So this number is likely to rise prior to the election. I believe this is an outstanding indicator that we are indeed developing informed, engaged citizens in Albemarle County Public Schools. And I thank you for giving me an opportunity to celebrate them tonight.

text: Yes, good evening board members. Pat McLaughlin back again, chief of strategic planning for the school division. And tonight I'll be sharing with you the latest local statistics about the COVID-19 crisis along with Eileen Gomez. And in addition, we'll be sharing some additional updates about our progress in preparing to move to stage three of our return to school plan.  So as you recall, we've identified six factors to determine our progression between stages of return. And at the board's request, we provide updates at each meeting on the current COVID-19 conditions in Albemarle County, in the Albemarle County region, and within the Albemarle County public schools, including, but not limited to, community transmission, testing positivity rates, and other health data. And at this time, I'll turn things over to Eileen to take us through our Albemarle and Charlottesville statistics from the Virginia Department of Public Health.
speaker: patrickmclaughlin

text: Good evening. Thank you, Dr. McLaughlin. I'm pleased to share with you this evening that our numbers and the trends over the last two weeks have been favorable. As you can see from this first slide, that these are some of the lowest numbers that we've experienced since we started presenting this data in August.  You can also see that the trends of all these numbers have been decreasing, which you'll recall means that over the last 14 days, each day has shown a directionality downward. The cases you'll recall are the number of cases per 100,000 of the population. Albemarle County, down to 6.4.  The next slide shows you Albemarle County's percent positivity, and this has dropped quite considerably. We're down to 2.5%, which is the lowest it's been in quite a while.  The next slide, the city of Charlottesville, you'll see that their numbers are still higher than ours, but they're a lot lower than they were, and they've been trending downward for at least the last two weeks. And the percent positivity of Charlottesville, you will see here, is extremely low, 1.8%, which is the lowest it's been since March.  So all of our numbers are looking good. And I checked in with the health department before this evening's meeting to see that we still have not had any outbreaks in any of the schools in the health district. And several of those surrounding areas have gone back, as you know. So I'm very pleased to report that.
speaker: eileengomez

text: So thanks Eileen and and as you all may recall from our last board meeting, the CDC recently released guidelines to assist schools as they plan to return students to the classroom. And these different just a little bit from the VDH metrics in that the CDC uses a 14 day cumulative count for case incidents, while the VDH uses the seven day average.  And you can see that the case incident rate in our area is declining, but it still sits in the higher risk category from the CDC. The CDC percent positivity is also calculated a bit differently as they use a 14 day average compared to a seven day average for the VDH. And as you can see here, that percent positivity for Albemarle County is down to 2.8 percent, which is in the lowest level of risk.  We left these dates we tried to match these dates up with when we get our updates from the Virginia Department of Health. But one thing I think is important to note is that as of yesterday, that percent positivity from the CDC had dropped to 2.0%. So, so as Eileen said, things are certainly trending.  in the right direction for us. And based on our current numbers and our case incidence rate places us in the higher risk of transmission and our percent positivity places us in the lowest risk of transmission category. I think it's important to note that the percent positivity has moved from the moderate level when we were with you two weeks ago to decide on stage three. So we've moved two full columns over in that metric in a positive way. And remember the third factor that the CDC identified  was mitigation strategies within the school, which are consistent and correct use of masks, social distancing to the largest extent possible, hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette, cleaning and disinfection, and contract tracing in collaboration with the local health department. And when schools implement all of these practices correctly and consistently, it lowers the overall risk of transmission in our schools, even when other factors are elevated.  We currently have all five mitigation strategies in place and we feel like we're implementing them correctly and consistently. It's also important to know that all four of these columns allow us to move into our stage three according to guidelines from the CDC and the DOE and the Virginia Department of Public Health.  One other piece of information I wanted to make you aware of is the launch of our ACPS COVID-19 dashboard. This dashboard can be found on our return to school page and gives information about any cases and outbreaks that have taken place within our schools or our departments. The dashboard is updated as cases are confirmed, but no less than once per week on our site.  And tonight we'd also like to expand our update a little bit by giving you some, some information on our progress towards stage three. We've received responses to date from 98% of our pre K through grade three families, and on average, 55% of our students have elected to return to the hybrid model, while 45% will remain virtual.  When we look at individual schools, we see that the range for families selecting hybrid was between 45% at our school with the lowest number of hybrid students to 73% at our school with the highest number of hybrid students. If you flip those numbers, you see the range for virtual. Our school with the lowest number of virtual students has 26.9% staying virtual and with the highest has 55.5% staying virtual.  And we also thought you'd be interested in the demographic breakdown of these responses. So the table on the left shows student choice by demographic group. So, if you took all of our all of all the white students who responded to the survey 55% chose hybrid and 45% chose virtual.  And the table on the right mirrors our equity dashboard. And this shows what percentage of each demographic group is represented in our hybrid and virtual models. So you can see that our demographic groups, this far right column is our total population for this current school year. And you can see that both the hybrid and virtual models mirror fairly closely the demographic breakdown that we have in our school. We don't see any great disparities here between those numbers.  with the percentage of students who are gonna make up both our hybrid and our virtual learning cohorts when we begin in November. And so at this time, I'd like to turn things over to Ms. Collins to provide some information about our K-3 schedules.
speaker: patrickmclaughlin

text: Good evening, I'm Debbie Collins, Deputy Superintendent. And I wanted to share with you some information about schedules for K-3 students as we move from stage two, virtual for all, to stage three, hybrid for some.  All virtual students will have a similar schedule to the one they have now. The day is divided into an a.m. and p.m. section. One is synchronous with their teacher and the other part of the day is mostly asynchronous with their specials included. For our students whose families chose hybrid, they will attend school on an every other day cycle. Face-to-face will look something like the schedule you see in front of you.  While the order may change, the time requirements are from the Virginia Standards of Learning. The next schedule is the Learning at Home schedule, and it may look something like this. Students will have support during the day from teaching assistants or other staff in the building to complete the assignments that they were assigned by their teacher the day before.  They will also continue to attend synchronous specials like art, music, and PE. So we wanted to share these schedules. We had some questions earlier about them, and these are the schedules that we have given to the principals, the elementary principals, as samples to follow as they develop, as the teachers and principals develop schedules together. Thank you.
speaker: debbiecollins

text: And I believe up next is Dr. Kaiser with an update on staffing.
speaker: patrickmclaughlin

text: Thank you, Dr. McLaughlin. I'm Claire Kaiser, assistant superintendent. One of the factors that allowed us to consider moving to stage three was ensuring that we had enough staff for that in-person learning hybrid model that was just shared. This evening, I will share our current state around it.  When the board made the decision to move to stage three, teachers and support staff were given the opportunity to apply for accommodations to teach virtually. If you look at the chart before you tonight, what you will see is the breakdown of those accommodation requests. You may remember that when surveyed, our teachers indicated that about a third of them would be requesting a virtual accommodation. Our numbers of actual requests show less than that, right? It depends on the grouping and the grade levels,  It ranges from about 3% in the ADA for the whole school division up a little higher than that as we go through each of the different areas. When you look at the breakdown here, the first column is of the total teachers.  And we divide that into requests based on the request associated with the Americans with Disabilities Act. The non-ADA category includes individuals who indicated a need for accommodation due to being in a CDC-identified high-risk category. They may be caregivers or live with somebody who is in a CDC high-risk category. They may have childcare issues, or they may have just generalized concerns about returning to work.  Our total number of teachers gives us the overall perspective as our numbers did when we did the survey. But we also wanted to show the numbers broken down by those most impacted by the return to in-person face-to-face learning. And so there you see the breakdown of kindergarten through third grade classroom teachers, special education teachers, ESL teachers, and then our regular education and special education teaching assistants. You can go to the next slide.  The numbers are really promising. Ms. Collins and I have been meeting with our elementary principals for staffing meetings over the course of last week and this week, and now we are meeting with our secondary principals. And in those meetings, they are sharing their plans for how they will utilize staff.  Now that we have a firmer indication of our student numbers and the request for hybrid and virtual learning, we are able to determine what some of our teaching needs are. And I am very pleased to say that any of the accommodation requests for those individuals with  an ADA accommodation request will be honored in stage three. For our non-ADA accommodation request, that's going to vary a little bit school by school. And because the numbers vary and the number of teachers at each school who made the request vary. And so we are using a process that aligns very much with what we do for our reduction in force process, where we have a limited number of positions that our teachers are  that are being considered for. So we're going through that process right now. We should have that wrapped up by early to mid next week. And we are hopeful that we will be able to accommodate as many people as possible. We do recognize that we will not be able to meet everybody's accommodation request.  If a person's accommodation request is not met, then they will be given the opportunity. We hope that they'll come in. That's really what we would like them to do. Our principals will work with them to make sure that they understand the mitigation strategies that will be in place. And we, again, are hopeful that they will come in. If they choose that they can't, then we will continue the opportunity for them to choose to take a leave of absence, or they may decide to resign or retire.  We are very pleased with the way that our staffing has come forward with all of this. And the bottom line here is that we have the ability to staff both the hybrid and the virtual needs of our students in Stage 3, as well as meet the accommodation needs of many, but not all, of those who requested to remain teaching virtually. And we are very grateful and thank our staff, our tremendous staff, for their willingness to step in in both the hybrid and the virtual models.

text: Good evening. I'm Lindsay Snoddy, Deputy Director of Building Services, and we're going to talk about High School Center 2 Schematic Design. Student capacity issues at both Albemarle High School and Western Albemarle High School have necessitated the need for additional instructional space. With that in mind, we studied our high schools as a 4,000-student high school system versus three distinct and separate comprehensive high schools, recognizing that all students should have the opportunity to participate in any academic program offered in the county.  Based on this, the recommendation was to use a village or center model to alleviate capacity issues and to modernize existing high school spaces. High School Center 2 is a 60,000 square foot facility with a 400 student per day capacity that is a resource for the entire division. It is strategically located to provide access to interdisciplinary project-based and specialized programming.  It will also serve as an interface between the school, community, and professional organizations that provide out-of-the-building authentic learning experiences such as internships and other work and community-based opportunities. The current goal is to open the Center 2 in spring 2023. Design funding for High School Center 2 was approved in FY19-20. However, funding for construction has not yet been appropriated.  Tonight's presentation is for information only. At the next meeting, we will recommend approval of the schematic design for High School Center 2 and authorization to proceed with the design development. Quinn Evans has their team here tonight, and they'll present the schematic design. And Charles Tilly will kick it off. Thank you, Charles.

So the design team conducted a series of three workshops that took place in the spring, summer, and fall of 2019, and engaged a group of about 20 ACPS administrators, teachers, and community partners. And the areas of focus included exploring 21st century learning goals for the state and district,  and their implications on the High School Center II facility, sharing best practice examples of school facilities designed and built within the past five to 10 years that modeled many of the design elements prioritized in the high school study, and discussing ACPS's particular school and district needs and priorities. And the highlights of these priorities include on the educational level, offsetting capacity overages at Albemarle High School and Western Albemarle High School,  Also creating programs that are relevant and flexible, putting discovery and innovation at the center of the learning experience and making it more visible. A focus on helping students to develop skills in collaboration and social emotional learning, incorporating PD into the process, and most importantly, graduating students that are thriving and ready for success in life. And community priorities included ensuring access to everyone,  and connecting to local business and resources and serving as a community have been resourced. Next slide. And during our workshops, we connected these goals and the high school study guiding principles to design features that were prioritized by the group. And when we think about community orientation and accessibility to all, we want to make sure that there's safe and welcoming arrival sequence, as well as clusters of learning within the building that build connection between spaces and that allow for  certain parts of the building to be safely used by the community after school hours. We also wanted to consider indoor-outdoor connections that allow for extending learning beyond the walls of the school. In terms of supporting the guiding principle of interdisciplinary learning, we want to make sure that the classrooms are agile and flexible and that they're also  extended learning spaces like breakout and commons areas that create these synergistic connections and support large groups, small group, and independent learning. Next slide. And to foster the guiding principles of life, career, citizenship, as well as student-designed environments that can be owned and customized by them, we looked again to providing multipurpose spaces that extend beyond the walls of the classroom  and provide spaces for flexible use and sustainability is also an important design focus as well as the idea that the building itself can teach students about sustainable energy use by enabling them to interact with and monitor building systems. And in terms of the guiding principles of mentored and authentic learning the building.  can support these by functioning like a high-performance work environment with varied and professional spaces, such as maker spaces and experimental and simulation labs. And finally, next slide, with regard to the guiding principle of transparency, we wanted to make sure that the building provides visible learning and connections, as well as good wayfinding and opportunities for display, exhibition, and storytelling. And next.  And we did talk to a group of about 20 students and eight teachers in two separate workshops about the kinds of spaces that most excited them. And what they were most excited about were the indoor-outdoor connections, maker spaces in a place that felt like a high-performance workspace, sustainability, and varied spaces with multi-purpose functions, including breakout spaces and STEM and STEAM.  Those were at the top of the list. And I'm going to turn this back to Charles and Kyla now to tell you how each of these considerations factored into the building design. Thanks, David.

And so these aren't corridors, but it's the circulation space, but they're wide spaces, creating different different size niches and spaces for students to occupy. It's student owned space outside of the classroom, outside the instructional space filled with furniture of different types and sizes to meet different people's needs and accommodate different types of work they might be doing.  interspersed in that space are group rooms, so more enclosed spaces for students to gather and do work outside classroom time, and then teacher collaboration spaces, which are really pretty casual teacher offices. Makes them available to students, but gives them a private place to go. The project studios and learning studios are really the core instructional spaces. We're not calling them classrooms. They're not your normal classrooms. They are really high function, high flexibility, adaptable, and agile spaces  Project studios are more intensive. Some of them will be outfitted like chemistry labs. Some of them like maker spaces. Learning studios are a little smaller, but still flexible. Flexible furniture throughout and resources like sinks and counter space and product storage in all of these spaces. And then operable partitions will be employed kind of strategically between these different studios to allow them to flex and get big or flex and get small.  kind of depending on the needs and as programs evolve and change. And then our specialty studios are the really hyper-specialized spaces like a wood shop or a metal shop, could be more high-tech digital environment like a recording studio or like a medical simulation lab perhaps, but that'll be, it's kind of TBD as we determine what programs go in here.  The idea lab is kind of the evolution of the typical library. You know, we don't need volumes of literature here necessarily, as it's more of a STEM focused center. So this is a place where students and teachers come together to access information, whether that's digital or analog. And it's partnered with this digital fabrication lab, which is a place where students can access technology such as 3D printers and laser scanners. It's that digital shop kind of space.  And there's no gym here, but we are including a fitness room or wellness room. And we think this is a pretty unique opportunity to address wellness and health from, you know, kind of all ends of the spectrum, from physical activity to mental health. It's a place where a student might go jump on an exercise bike, you know, for 10 minutes between class to kind of get that energy out or the workout in. You know, or there could be a yoga class, you know, first thing in the morning or at the end of the day. So multifunctional space to kind  view the whole student as a holistic whole and address health as well. And of course, the outdoor spaces are really important at a school where we're making a lot of stuff. So projects are big and dirty and messy, and being able to get outside is important. So on all sides of the building, these project studios and learning studios on this front side of the building have direct access to the outside. This area spills out into what we're calling the fabrication yard.  And even the commons spills out to an outdoor dining terrace.
